text: Can you tell me what orthopedics means?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Orthopedics is a subspecialty in medicine that deals with the spinal column that includes the neck, mid back, and low back, and all of the structures that are associated with it, including the disks and nerves that supply motor and sensory function to the extremities, also deals with the joint areas, the muscles, tendons, and ligaments and internal structures in the joints, and then nerves and vessels that travel in the extremities. We also deal with people who have traumatic injuries to those areas, individuals who have arthritic conditions, and certainly we treat conservatively and have the training to do surgery in those areas if the need arises.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you tell the jury please about the process of becoming an orthopedic surgeon?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: The process after graduating medical school and doing a one-year internship entails a four-year program wherein you are just doing orthopedics and taking care of patients who come through the emergency facility.  You get the opportunity to be in clinic setting, sometimes in private physicians' offices.  So you are getting a well-rounded education in that regard and then actually going to the operating room and participating in surgeries and doing the surgeries under the direction of the individuals who have privileges in the hospital setting and also outpatient settings as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you tell the jury how long you've been a physician?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: I've been a physician since 1981.  That's when I graduated medical school.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you board certified?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Yes, I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In what specialties?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: I hold certificates in orthopedics and pain management.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What does board certification mean?
speaker: MR. FLAHERTY

text: Well, in the surgical subspecialty it means that you've met the requirements of independently incorporated boards.  There is three of them in Pennsylvania.  I'm certified by one of them.  They are recognized as equal. So when you meet the requirements, taking tests and then the last year actually being watched doing surgery by board certified individuals, who also review your charts in the hospital and office setting for the two years before, you receive a certificate.  So that's for me 1989 my first certificate. After that there is recertification, and that just entails taking written tests, and I have done that successfully three times up to 2011, and I hold the certificate that designates Emeritus status.

text: Well, shoulder anatomy is very interesting, because it's not like the hip, in that you have the head of the bone sitting in a socket.  There is a socket in the shoulder, but it sits pretty much vertically, and it is very, very shallow.  So the head will ride in that socket, and the stabilization for the head is four tendons that are the rotator cuff, and the four tendons spell the words S.I.T.S, S-I-T-S. The head is the humeral head, and above the head is a bone that you can actually touch in your own shoulder.  It's squared off at the edge.  That comes off the scapula which is called the acromion, and then there is the clavicle which is the collarbone which meets the acromion and forms a joint.  So all of these anatomical structures that I just mentioned make up what we call the shoulder girdle. Inside the joint on the socket is a lip that's called the labrum, and that cushions the head as it rides or moves in the socket when you go through range of motion.  There is a plexus of nerves that sit in that area as well right in front of the head.  It's called the brachial plexus, so that supplies motor and sensory function as well as the nerves that comes out of the neck and form those nerves that eventually fan off into the extremities.
